snippet.textDisplay:
Markets are not a democracy.
The problem isnt gamers, the problem lies in premise that you can boycott something just by deciding not to buy it.
It's like trying to solve climate change by deciding to go recycle more. The folly of neoliberal capitalism that emphasizes self destructive individualism against power.

Gamers must organize and take on these powerful cooperate enities in a meaningful material way. Untill then whatever vendetta you or I have against whatever company is pointless.

snippet.textDisplay:
"Gamer boycotts" do not work for 3 reasons:

1) Although adult gamers can read through bullshit, games as products are fun looking things that kids want to play with. Kids and their parents are not critical of 'artistic integrity' or anything else like that. Kids want game, mommy and daddy fork up dollars. That's it.

2) FOMO - fear of missing out. If all your friends play an online game, there's an incentive to purchase the game so that you can be a part of the fun, (even shitty games are great with your buds). Even if the game is a bloated data hogging pile of shit. (Looking at you COD)

3) Organizing anything (not just boycotts) at a national level is insanely difficult and requires A LOT of people to care deeply about something. Video games arnt that deep bro.

snippet.textDisplay:
A friendly reminder that what happens on the internet is not only not real, but has zero impact on reality or the day to day life of people, businesses or politics. Twitter can be as angry as it wants to be over whatever its decides, but that doesn't translate even a tiny bit to anything tangible in the real world. You can't tweet a politician out of office, you can't upvote to bankrupt a business, and you can change the world with an internet petition.


Its also a healthy remind that the real world is not represented by the internet, a giant gaming subreddit full of angry customers is meaningless because maybe 1% of them are actually angry, and they are only 1% of 1% of the people who matter, IE: the actual paying customers, who don't visit forums or reddit or watch youtube videos over a pokemon game. They buy it because its pokemon and that is that and they don't care and they aren't listening to you, you don't matter even a fraction of a percent to their lives.

snippet.textDisplay:
Ah, I think I see wherein the problem lies.

To say that you're boycotting something is not the idea. To boycott, you need not say anything. Boycotting rests on not benefiting financially the party you intend to boycott. So if you want to boycott a gaming company, you are to not, I repeat, to NOT buy their game(s).

Hope that clears things up a bit.

snippet.textDisplay: The problem is gaming communities are too separated and segmented by their nature.  As much as we can brew up a storm when something goes down that we don't like, there's usually a much larger multitude of gamers that simply can't be assed to do anything.  And that's fine.  It's like in politics, it affects everyone who lives in a country, but a majority of people are not full all-in gung-ho about getting their political point across or even reading deep enough into the system to do so.  Some people just want to live in reasonable comfort in their house in the country they're an honest upright citizen of.  Some gamers just want to pop in a game every now and again and don't care to see the noise unless it goes so far as to swarm right in their face.  That's why game boycotts will rarely work, if ever, and if they do it's not for very long, and I can liken that factor to politics as well but I digress.

snippet.textDisplay:
hey Jim, not sure if you'd be interested in looking into it, but Nintendo Mobile just released a new subscription "service" for one of it's f2p mobile games (the Feh Pass for Fire Emblem Heroes), and it costs over $100 a year and gates off quality of life changes from non-subscribers. it's generally being horribly received by the fanbase for previously stated reasons (along with the fact that the game loves to remind people of it by flaunting said-QoL changes all over the game and telling players they've "completed" Feh Pass quests that they can't actually claim rewards for without buying a subscription), but I understand if you're too busy or it's just not something you want to cover, I just felt I couldn't not bring it up as a long-time fan who loves watching you tear apart skeezy money-making schemes from the already ultra-rich. not to mention being a long-time player of Fire Emblem Heroes as well, which has just made the whole Feh Pass thing very infuriating to me personally, so I thought it was worth mentioning.


Sorry to only be adding this as an after-thought, but I loved the video, as always you did a great job!

snippet.textDisplay:
I feel like the people who say they're going to boycott a game-any game-are in the minority. Like with Pokemon-it's a really fun game, but it still markets mainly towards children, and most children either aren't going to be aware of the controversy or don't care. Even if everyone who said they'd boycott went through with it, the game would've still sold a lot. Same with other games-a lot of people just don't care enough to get mad.


The biggest backlash is usually when something just completely sucks ass (Battlefront) or, in the case of Warcraft Reforged, effects other games (fucked up Warcraft 3 classic).

snippet.textDisplay: Damned if you do, damned if you don't.  At this point in time I'm actively boycotting Blizzard, Bethesda, and EA, though I've considered purchasing Fallen Order as I believe voting with your wallet means casting a vote of 'yes' if a company does something you agree with. All I've managed to do is deprive myself of entertainment while sticking to my guns, which may as well be loaded with blanks.

So even if everyone that said they would boycott the game actually did so, it likely wouldn't have mattered much at all.

snippet.textDisplay:
The problem with the "gamer boycott" is that most of the time, the term is used by some person who wishes to insist that his choice not to buy a game needs to have some greater worldwide significance.


I don't buy Squeenix games, because I hate Squeenix's practices. I don't buy goldfish crackers anymore, either, precisely because of a decision they made years ago to increase the package size. While both of these decisions might technically fit the definition of "boycott", I don't call it such, because I don't really care to broadcast every decision I make...
...
...except these decisions, apparently. Just shut up.

snippet.textDisplay:
There are many, many games I haven't bought or played, and many films and shows I haven't seen or given money to out of principal of bad business practices or just bad product.

I don't really trust, Jim, that what examples were shown were representative of boycotts in general when the examples were of two of the most 'basic' and, frankly, infantile consooomer fan bases around.

My point is that I think it's bad to generally characterize "not buying something" as what Pokémon nerds lie about, and that you can both complain to the developers of BF2 without also HAVING ALREADY GIVEN THEM YOUR MONEY.

Voting with your wallet is a solid strategy for people who aren't brainless children.

snippet.textDisplay:
Until you get over your desire to buy every game in a series, companies will never respect you. Until you actually withhold your financial support and stand on principle, it's all meaningless. Get another hobby and spend your money on that. That way, even if the games never get better, you won't care because you'll have other means of keeping yourself entertained. If your happiness is dependent on Pokemon or Modern Warfare, theres no incentive for Nintendo or Activision to listen to you. Let go of your codependency and you'll be a stronger person with broader horizons.

Jim, we welcome you to Pennsylvania, where every road is a winding path and every liquor store is a public works project.
